talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - Who made them the victims?

The Government has abandoned similar forms of assistance to Cambodia. It has abandoned also the provision of humanitarian assistance to Cambodia. We have downgraded SEATO with the intention of abandoning it completely at the earliest possible moment. We have made bitter attacks on the United States of America; we have insulted France; and we have launched attacks upon a number of other countries. We have also abolished national service and, according to a statement by Professor O'Neill of the Australian National University, left the Australian Army in chaos. We have ended the provision of a program of naval instruction.

continue.para: I regret that Senator Turnbull should have interjected earlier. I have been informed that he went on television tonight and adopted a holier than thou attitude and said that the senators who interjected and performed last night had acted in a scandalous way. He said that in his opinion the senators were under the influence of drink. If Senator Turnbull feels that way about it, the least he can do is set an example by conducting himself in an orderly fashion.

I conclude by saying that I hope that the parliamentarians in the Australian Labor Party will get behind Mr Whitlam and Mr Barnard and agree with them that there shall be at least some Australian presence in that area. I hope they will be true to the promises they made to the people when they said that they would worthily represent those who voted for them. I hope that they will not instead indicate that they take their instructions from a body outside the parliamentary Labor Party.

talker.role: Minister for Repatriation and Minister assisting the Minister for Defence
talker.name: BISHOP, Reginald
Senator BISHOP

talk.start.para: - I think "that there is a certain amount of hypocrisy in the proposition that Senator McManus has put forward tonight. This is the second occasion in a debate on bases and the troops in Singapore that he has told us about the constructive role that is being played by the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Barnard) and applauded that role. Senator McManus has asked us to ensure that members of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party get behind Mr Whitlam and Mr Barnard and see that their moderate attitude is supported.
Yo u will have a job. You will not get behind them because they have their backs to the wall.

Her e we go again. Honourable senators opposite will not listen to what we on this side of the chamber have to say. While doing that, Senator McManus proposed and supported a proposition initially put forward by his Leader, Senator Gair, which, among other things, states:

quote.para: . . . furthermore, the Senate condemns that the policy of the Federal Government on this vital security question will be determined by a body not responsible to the Federal Parliament—the Federal Conference of the Australian Labor Party.

continue.para: On the one hand he says, 'Barnard is a great bloke. He can be relied upon. He is sincere and honest', and on the other he says, 'Barnard is also no good'. He says that the Federal Conference of the Australian Labor Party has acted as a determinant of the policies of the Government. That is hypocritical to me. If Senator McManus wants to introduce into this Parliament the idea that he supports a certain group within the Labor Party he should come out cleanly and say so. He should also give his reasons. But he should not introduce this sort of hypocrisy into the proceedings. Senator Gair's motion includes the following:

quote.para: That the Senate unequivocally supports the retention of Australian defence units ia Singapore.

continue.para: Senator McManus does not say: 'Look, we ought to rely upon our advisers'. He says that 'they' say tbis and 'they' say that and Lee Kuan Yew says this and the Malaysians say that, but there is no informed opinion behind his arguments. Instead he says that the Labor Government has made a lot of mistakes. He refers to the mistakes, as he sees them, in our quick recognition of communist China. The honourable senator talks about our getting out of Vietnam and then refuses to recognise that in all these moves the United States Government has been a party to what has happened and has agreed with the decisions that have been made. The honourable senator will not accept that position, yet everybody knows that an arrangement has been made in Vietnam between President Nixon and Dr Kissinger of the United States of America and Chou En-lai and Hanoi in relation to the Vietnam position. That is evident to everybody who reads a newspaper even if he does not study the matter in depth. Dr Kissinger for many months—i n fact almost years—ha s been doing the communication rounds in establishing what has now become a peace in Vietnam.

Senator McManus tried to twist the facts to show that the Australian Government has failed to defend the South Vietnamese. He then tried to say that it would be all right if we supported the Americans. There has been a realistic trend on the part of the United States Government jn trying to estabJisb peace in Vietnam. The Australian Government has gone along with the United States Government on this matter. The Australian Government wants to see that the peace treaty works and, like President Nixon and Dr Kissinger, it has said that as soon as peace is perfect and established Australia will help to reconstruct both North Vietnam and South Vietnam. That is the practical reality of politics and foreign affairs throughout the world. The DLP does not see it that way because it still wants to fight the wars of yesteryear. As was mentioned yesterday, members of the DLP are still looking at the old struggles of the Spanish War and have forgotten that the Spanish Government now recognises East Germany and that Willy Brandt has become the saviour of Europe by making an arrangement to enable East Germany and West Germany to meet.

Willy Brandt is the most outstanding politician in the world. Willy Brandt is a Labor man— a social democrat. He is the leader of a Party like the Labor Party and is the equivalent of Mr Whitlam in Australia. Willy Brandt has achieved in Europe the things which Mr Whitlam is trying to do here. We have the same outlook. The ALP has an Australian outlook. Having an Australian outlook we support the Prime Minister, and as members of the parliamentary Labor Party we will decide parliamentary tactics and we, with the help of our advisers in the fields of defence and foreign affairs will make the decisions. If Senator McManus believes that this is a good outlook to have, surely he would say that Mr Barnard is a good man. He should not then bring in the last stroke of the dagger by saying that the Labor Party will fail because it depends on the Federal Conference. Senator McManus and Opposition senators are trying to be divisive and to separate within the Labor Party people who have different shades of opinion. The Labor Party has always been a Party in which there have been different shades of opinion. When Senator McManus was a member of the Labor Party there were within the Party differences of political thought on domestic and foreign issues. That situation has not changed and it will never change because the ALP is a concensus party.

The Australian Labor Party is like some of the political parties of Europe. It has taken its traditions from the British Labor movement and from the social democrat parties. Surely relationships between the Australian Labor Party and Lee Kuan Yew, who is a social democrat and a member of the Socialist International, are better than relations would be between the ALP and the DLP. Our relationships with Willy Brandt are better than our relationships with the DLP. We believe in an Australian outlook. For this reason, and having in mind that we in Australia should have a capacity to run our own country, a defence capacity and competence, the ALP has studied the position and considered to what extent our forces which are now overseas should be stationed within Australia or outside Australia. The Government, not only on its own account but also acting on expert advice, has decided that Australian troops in Singapore should be withdrawn.

Senator Jessop is trying to say something. What is he talking about? He would not even know the area. I doubt that he knows what he is talking about when he mentions the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I remind the Senate of what I said earlier—tha t we have an Australian outlook. I am glad that Senator McManus has spoken about former leaders of the Labor Party. Is the tradition of the Labor Party any different now from what it was in the days when Curtin and Chifley ran the Labor Party? It is not. The Australian Labor Party is just as strongly Australian as it was then. In those days, as honourable senators will be aware, it was Curtin who decided to jack up on Churchill and the British Government, and both Chifley and Curtin said that an Australian competence had to be applied in running Australia.

talk.start.para: - It was Chifley who put troops into the coal mines.
The honourable senator is trying to divert the argument.
- No, I am just putting in what you are leaving out.

In those earlier years Labor Prime Ministers always approached things from an Australia standpoint. We now have a Labor Government again and that Government has taken over the control of the Australian nation. The Government will run the country on Australian lines. Senator McManus has talked about day to day control as though Mick Young was breathing down the Prime Minister's neck. I ask anyone who knows those individuals: Is it more likely that Mick Young would be able to influence Mr Whitlam than the DLP would?
- What was he doing flying in the VIP aircraft with Whitlam? The Minister cannot see anything wrong with that, apparently.

But apparently Senator Little can. Are honourable senators aware of the influences which split the Australian Labor Party and which are now breathing down the neck of the DLP? Of course they are. We are all aware that some honourable senators opposite accept that these influences exist. Last night many Liberal members of the Opposition were surprised and disappointed at the action that was taken. Despite the coalition of groups that make up the Opposition, some honourable senators opposite were disappointed and did not want to follow the DLP which, I am glad to say, was defeated.

continue.para: I have mentioned that the ALP is a democratic party. In our Party there are shades of opinion, as everybody knows and accepts. I do not disguise the fact that there are these shades of difference. But there is no day to day control. Already we have heard statements by the Prime Minister on the subject, and both the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Barnard) have been applauded by Senator McManus. We have a situation in which the honourable senator is saying that the Labor Government has two fine leaders whose policies are good, but in which he then goes on to ask whether we can trust the Labor Government to run the country. I suggest that the evidence is quite clear. The Prime Minister is in control in this country. There is no suggestion or possibility that somebody other than the Federal Labor Party will run this Government. Because the Labor Party is a democratic party, if a Federal Conference establishes a policy the Government must be guided to some extent by that policy and it will take note of it. But on no account would the government of the country be delegated to outside bodies. The honourable senator should know that because of what has happened already.

What is the approach by members of the DLP in this situation? They rely on so-called Press leaks. They say that there are reports in the newspapers that the Labor Party Caucus wants to talk about foreign bases in Australia or the troops in Singapore. Why should the Caucus not want to talk about these things? Labor's policy on these subjects is well established and well known. The Government has come into this chamber and the other place and has stated its policy, and members of the ALP have supported their leaders in those policies. I suggest that what the DLP is doing is nothing more than hypocrisy. It is trying to increase whatever tensions it sees within the Labor Party. Of course the DLP will not support the Labor Party. Whatever members of the DLP say about the goodness of Chifley and Curtin, who are now dead, at the first opportunity they will make an arrangement with the Country Party or Liberal Party to undo the work that we have done.

talk.start.para: - The DLP is leading the Liberal Party by the nose.

Unti l now the Liberal Party has been closely following whatever the DLP has proposed, but I suggest after last night that many members of the Liberal Party do not agree with what has been done. I hope that those members will consider seriously the sorts of associations that they have had with the DLP. In moving this motion Senator McManus' motives were not the best or the most constructive. He and other members of his Party are not concerned about defence. Rather, they are concerned about how they can attack the Labor Government. After all, the Labor Party has been elected as the Australian Government. The Opposition, and groups in the Opposition, small or large, ought to give the Labor Government a go and ought to support its policies where they are clear and identifiable.

continue.para: The motion, as I have pointed out, does not deal with the realities of the situation. Rather it implies that the whole security of Australia depends on our having a section of a battalion or a regiment. The charges that Senator McManus made about the differences between Australia and Britain and America are false. Our relationships with the United States of America and Great Britain are good. The British, of course, are well established in diplomacy. I do not think that anybody could outdate the British in assessing political situations and the British are with Australians in all the things that we want to do. If the Australian Government says that it wants to shift the entire battalion from Singapore, the British and the Americans will go along with us. We know that in order to assist other countries it is better to have efficiency and competence within this country where we have a great backup of industry and skills and an excellently trained army.

What Senator McManus said about the Australian forces is not true. The Australian defence forces today are better than they have ever been. Of course, we rejected national service because it was the thing which divided the Australian population. As I have stated in answers to questions in this Parliament, one-third of our national servicemen have now decided to remain within the Army. Our recruitment to the Australian Army is satisfactory. We have taken initiatives in relation to the Air Force and the Army, and we have retained our shipbuilding competence for our defence. Our shipbuilding industry was running down under the old Government. Everybody knows that at the end of the year Australian shipyards building ships for the Navy for defence purposes did not have a job and many men were threatened with unemployment. As soon as we came to power Mr Barnard, the Minister for Defence, quickly said that there should be no retrenchment and asked the defence organisations to set up jobs for these people quickly.

Our record in the aircraft industry is clear. We have sent a mission overseas to make arrangements to get a replacement for the Mirage, and we have told Australian aircraft manufacturers to get together and present a report to us by June. We have done this to ensure that the competence we have in this country is organised. For 20 years many people who are not Labor Party supporters have pointed to the failure of the old Government in letting this competence disappear. This is well known to everybody. Therefore why does Senator McManus say that the Australian Government has not discharged its policies relating to our defence capacity? Apart from all the things I have spoken about already, there is no question that there is a better spirit in the Australian Services today because of what we have done. We have increased the pay of servicemen. We will spend $63m on updating pay rates in all the Services. The proposals in the report on the defence forces retirement benefits scheme which was rejected by the McMahon Government will soon come into effect. In addition, we have set out a program under which consideration will be given to the extent to which accommodation and standards within the Services ought to be improved. The Government proposes also to appoint an ombudsman within the Services. AH these are practical things. They are ihings that can be considered and can be dealt with.

The motion deals narrowly with Australian military units in Singapore. It does not deal with the total Australian contribution to ANZUK. It certainly ignores the total canvas of Australian policies. It ignores background and foreground and focuses on some minor military particle of the arrangements. We believe that there is a co-operative need, and we are pledged to meet that co-operative need under this arrangement. I want to quote what the Prime Minister said in this regard. He said:

quote.para: Pending neutralisation, we will honour the full terras of the 'Five Power Arrangements under which Auslralia agrees to provide Malaysia and Singapore with personnel, facilities and courses for training their forces and assistance in operational and technical matters and the supply of equipment. . . . The Five Power Arrangements do not require an Austrahan garrison in Singapore; the battalion and battery there will not be replaced when they complete their tour of duty.

continue.para: That platform was put to the people and we have a mandate to carry it out. May I remind honourable senators opposite that the former Government did not accept that there ought to be a permanent establishment in Singapore. Rather it considered it as a temporary arrangement. This Government is saying that within Australia there will be a defence competence and, as required, there will be arrangements for training Australian forces and those of our neighbours who have friendly relations with us and who, in this area, are developing new points of view. Those of us who read the newspapers and follow foreign affairs know well that the ideas of Malaysia about Butterworth, and the ideas of Lee Kuan Yew about the old need to establish British and Australian forces in Singapore, are changing. If countries believe that they have a neighbour like Australia which is competent and can be relied on to help train their own troops, and can be relied upon for support if there is ever a need for it, they will seek our co-operation. The Prime Minister has stated clearly that that is what we intend to do.

In my opinion the present arrangements are satisfactory. The time is quickly approaching when Australia will withdraw all of its troops and this action will not be considered by the British or the Americans as a mistake or as a deterrent to them. Rather will it be a new arrangement based on the new concept of Australia having regard for its new national identity. There is no requirement for an Australian garrison or ground combat troops to be stationed forever in Singapore. This Government says that that should not be whereas the previous Government maintained that they should be there for some time. The forms of co-operation in which we intend to engage, and in which we are obliged to engage, are those set out in Annex 1 of our bilateral international agreement with Singapore. I intend to read that Annex to the Senate. It is headed 'Assistance by Australia to the Singapore Armed Forces'. The terms agreed to require Australia to provide certain things. The Annex states:

quote.para: The Government of Australia shall provide as may be agreed between the Government of Singapore and the Government of Australia and on such terms, including terms as to payment, as may be agreed:
(a) personnel to assist in the staffing, administration and training of the Singapore Armed Forces;
(b) facilities, including instructional courses abroad, for training members of the Singapore Armed Forces;
(c) expert advice and assistance in operational and technical matters;
(d) use of facilities for the purposes of this Note; and
(e) assistance in the supply of equipment for the Singapore Armed Forces.

continue.para: We will assist in those matters. Senator McManus raised the question of the Australian battalion and battery and said that these comprise a ground combat force designed to provide ground combat capability. But we have to ask this question: Against whom will they be used? There is no identifiable force opposed at present to the country. Our relationships with other countries are good. As I said earlier, I suggest that our relationships, as a government formed by a social democratic Labor Party and headed by the present Prime Minister, are better than the relationships of the Liberal-Country Party coalition because all our members belong to the same Party. Of course there must be a better understanding. I remind the Senate that recently the Prime Minister of Australia visited New Zealand. Everybody knows the public reaction to that visit. There is perfect understanding between the Prime Minister of New Zealand and the Prime Minister of Australia. Only tonight we have had a dinner on the occasion of one of the first visits to Australia by a Labor Minister. He is the Labor Minister for Immigration from New Zealand. We expect that our relations with New Zealand will be better than they were under the last Government.

What can we expect in relation to the British presence or the United States presence and their interests? I think it is stupid to say, as Senator McManus said, that because the conflict in Vietnam has closed down and because we have stopped national service we have failed to assist our friends. We are standing. It is not written and it is not known well explained, the Americans, the Russians and the Chinese obviously have an understanding. It is not written and it is not know but we know that the understanding is there. We know that for many years the Soviet Union and the United States have had an understanding about Europe. There has been a detente in relation to Germany. That understanding has been a good thing for the world. I suggest that in relation to South East Asia there are these unwritten understandings, so We have to give them a try. We are saying in relation to South East Asia generally that what we propose to do is not inconsistent with what the Americans or the British want to do. Rather we are clarifying in a more positive way what Australia might have wanted to do under a coalition government. We make no excuses for that. We are an Australian party. We are the biggest party in Australia. We certainly have a policy. We are not dictated to. A policy is made by the peopie who comprise the Labor Party. The Prime Minister has clearly stated on the mandate which he has been given by the people what our policies are.

In relation to South East Asia and Singapore we expect that when we withdraw the troops our relationships with our neighbours will be no worse. They will be better because our neighbours will be able to better rely upon the Australian competence about which I told the Senate. I am pleased to say that in my short term in the Ministry in association with the Minister for Defence we have been able to bring about some more positive actions on the lines about which 1 have spoken. They are good things because they represent a greater strength within the Australian competence and a better back-up for the Australian Services. I suggest that the motion which has been put forward by the Australian Democratic Labor Party is like the proposition which it put forward in the Senate last night. It is largely a bit of political manoeuvring. It is partly a bit of hypocrisy. It should be rejected by any decent Australian and by any decent Liberal. I hope that the Senate will not support it because it would not be in the interests of Australia. It should be the role of the Senate to support the Government even though, in the Senate, it may not have the numbers. In circumstances where there are clear indications that the Government is putting forward to the Australian people policies for which it has a mandate— w e have a mandate for what I have spoken about— I suggest that the Senate should support the Government.

talk.start.para: - I am not very concerned with paragraph 2 of the motion except to say that we are entitled to take note of the statements which have been made by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Barnard), by Mr Hawke who warned the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) that he had to take note of the Federal Conference of the Australian Labor Party and by men such as Mr Hartley and Mr Crawford who are very prominent in the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party.
Her e we go again.

They are friends of the honourable senator. He should be quiet in this place because he might be forced to contradict Senator Bishop in a moment over what they have said. Let him stand up and be counted and not sit there chattering like a croaking cockatoo. I am not concerned that Senator Bishop has given us an assurance that the Government will govern in the national interest. I wiil accept that assurance and I will be interested to see whether the Government, if ordered by the Federal Conference of the Labor Party to withdraw all troops from Singapore, will obey the Federal conference. I think that will be a crunch situation. I accept the assurance of Senator Bishop that the Government will not. The only matter with which I am concerned is whether the Government, if it believes that the presence of some troops in Singapore—whateve r the number may be—i s in the national interest, will oppose any pressures from any source to act against the national interest. Having said that I leave the matter to the control of the Australian Labor Party. I do not think that is terribly germane to the first part of this motion.

continue.para: I wish I could believe that there was peace in Vietnam. I sincerely hope that there is. But obviously the United States Pentagon and President Nixon are becoming rather concerned at what they claim to be clear sightings of large numbers of North Vietnamese troops and armoured equipment moving down the Ho Chi Minh trail into Laos and towards South Vietnam. A warning has been issued that they fear there could be another outbreak of fighting when the wet season ends in some 6 weeks time.

talk.start.para: - I think that Mr Hartley has said that he hopes the North wins, has he not?

I do not want to be led onto another path at the moment. Senator Webster. I sincerely hope that this is not so. Also there is the continuing presence of some 13 divisions of regular North Vietnamese troops in South Vietnam. As long as that situation remains I do not believe we can accept with complete confidence that peace in Vietnam is assured. Of course this raises all sorts of problems. But at the moment I shall deal specifically with Singapore and the Five Power Arrangements. The Prime Minister in his policy speech gave a complete assurance that Auslralia would honour its obligation under the Five Power Arrangements. We are entitled to accept with complete assurance that whatever happens the Prime Minister's policy speech will be adhered to. But I am afraid that since this Government has been in office its actions have undermined the credibility of the Government and of Australia in South East Asia. I will come to that in a moment.

continue.para: Whatever people may wish to believe. South East Asia is not secure. To believe otherwise is wishful thinking. No-one is more conscious of this than the countries of South East Asia. Thailand has been in the news a little bit lately. 1 shall say something about Thailand in a few moments. Malaysia is being subjected to communist subversion on its northern borders and this has been spreading. This is also happening in Sarawak. The Malaysian revolutionary radio in South China has been broadcasting continuously to Malaysia. The radio in China has been broadcasting messages urging the patriots of Thailand to fight against the lawful government of that country. We have had complaints by Thailand— I believe that these complaints can be well proved—tha t the insurgents in the north are being provided with material and moral support from North Vietnam.

In this situation one cannot be certain that the stability of the area is assured—fa r from it. Indonesia is concerned, and no doubt the Prime Minister was told quite clearly when he was there, as I was told in the middle of December, by the Indonesians of their concern not only as to the dangers of instability in the region and of Australian policy but also as to the dangers within Indonesia itself. It may be that some peple wiU claim that the Indonesians over-reaction to the threat of Chinese communism. Nevertheless, the fear is there, ln 1965 they went through a traumatic experience and it is still fresh in their memories. There can be no doubt that the countries of South East Asia wish Australia to retain its forces in Singapore. There is no question of that. Mr Lee Kuan Yew— I pay great tribute to him despite what Senator Poyser's friend Mr Crawford had to say about him—wishe s the Australian forces to remain because he believes that they provide stability. The Malaysians wish them to remain. The Thais wish them to remain. Strangely enough, the Indonesians are now expressing publicly their wish that the Australian forces should remain and that the Five Power Arrangements should remain intact.

It is interesting that thc Indonesians are now taking this altitude, because in the past they have been, to put it mildly, luke warm towards what they regarded as military pacts in the South East Asian region. They have now changed their point of view. One must wonder and question why they have changed it. Obviously they have changed it because they still fear for the stability of the region. I think this is important. I think it is important also— I started to say this before I was interrupted by one of my colleagues—tha t we be very careful that we do not start dismantling agreements until we have something better to take their place, something that gives the assurance of stability to the countries of Asia. If we start to dismantle the Five Power Agreements, and if we follow the attitude of the Governnient towards the South East Asia Treaty Organisation and start to dismantle that, there will be a vacuum because we have not been able to provide any alternative to take its place—a n alternative which gives an assurance not to us but to the countries of South East Asia which seek that assurance.

Senator Bishop spoke of the Five Power Arrangements and questioned whether we believe that they should have a long term effect. Let me make it quite clear to Senator Bishop that I do not believe either that they should or that they will. I believe that the Five Power Arrangements will have a limited life, but so long as the countries of the region wish them to be maintained, because of our interest in maintaining the stability of the region and the confidence of the countries in the region, we have a clear responsibility to maintain them. If we do not do so, we not only destroy our credibility but also begin to destory the confidence of the people of the region.

talk.start.para: - That is your opinion.

It might be my opinion, but if the honourable senator has a different opinion he should prove it, because the opinion I express is the view of the people of the region. It is the view of Lee Kuan Yew, the social democrat and member of the Socialist International. He believes in that view. Lee Kuan Yew believes in the domino theory. He was asked whether he believed in the domino theory and he said: 'Yes'. Someone asked him why and he said: 'Because I am one of the dominoes'. It is all right for honourable senators opposite to express views here in Parliament House in Canberra, but if they were, as Mr Lee Kuan Yew believes he is one of the dominoes, they would have a slightly different attitude. 1 repeat that it is unwise for us to start dismantling defence arrangements until we have something to take their place, which we have not.

continue.para: Maybe we are starting to move towards something. I sincerely hope that we are. I hope that the Association of South East Asian Nations will prove to be stronger; but any one of us who at the moment has great faith that ASEAN can provide security and stability to the region is indeed an optimist, and a dangerous optimist. When the countries of South East Asia themselves feel secure and confident, we can have some confidence that the security of the region is likely to be maintained. At the moment they do not have that confidence. It is in our national interests that there should be security and stability in the South East Asian region. Nothing could be more tragic for Australia than to find grave internal problems arising in Indonesia. Nothing could be more tragic to Australia than to find Malaysia and Singapore under threat.

There may be some bright people who will say: 'They are not under threat'. Senator Bishop tells us that we now have a new world in which there is some unwritten understanding between the Soviet Union and China and the United States of America and Japan and China. AH I can say is that, if one reads the Russian Press and the statements made by Russian leaders, one finds that Russia has no understanding with China because the Russians constantly are warning us against Chinese imperialism and the military threat from China. Maybe the Russians are wrong. Recently the Chinese made the most bitter attack on Russia that has been made for years. They accused the Russians of absorbing territory that rightly belonged to China and giving towns and cities Russian names. If we look at the Soviet Union's move into the Indian Ocean, its obvious growing interest in South East Asia and its obvious desire to maintain a strong influence in Hanoi, we find that this in part—an d in big part—i s a move to counter what it believes is a growing Chinese influence.

Again people may argue about this and may state different views as to Russia's priorities. But I believe that most informed people on foreign affairs express the view that Russia is continuing to try to obtain more and more influence in the South East Asian region. Maybe it is doing so in its own national interest as a world power. Nevertheless, there is an element—an d a big element—o f fear of China and desire to contain China. I do not believe there is that understanding of which Senator Bishop speaks. Nor do the countries of South East Asia believe that China has yet changed its strategy and its tactics. There have been some faint noises from Peking to the effect that the Chinese are not as interested as they were in promoting insurgency. But Prince Sihanouk had something to say about this situation a little while ago. Tliere are all sorts of rumours as to the Australian Government's attitude towards Prince Sihanouk. A little while ago he made it clear that Mao Tse-tung's China has not changed its policy in relation to the promotion of insurgency. As late as 1971 the Chinese were considering sending volunteers into Cambodia.

So, Indonesia is concerned about Chinese policy. Indonesia is concerned at the way in which Australia moved so quickly to recognise Peking, and is expressing that opinion. The other countries of South East Asia also are concerned because they believe it weakens their ability to bargain.

I should like to read to the Senate an extract from an article written by a respected and well informed foreign correspondent, Mr Denis Warner, which was published in the 'Sydney Morning Herald' of Monday, 5th February of this year. Before any member of the Government starts to say anything about Mr Denis Warner, I remind them that I have heard him praised even by members of the Government when he said things that apparently suited them. In this article Mr Warner clearly proves the points which I am making—tha t there is this concern in South East Asia about China, that these, countries are still not satisfied and want far more proof before they will accept China's good intentions, and that they are concerned about the trend in Australia's policy. Mr Warner said:

quote.para: The Malaysians wanted more than Peking's suggestion that they should read into the diminished propaganda the assurances they sought.

continue.para: Apparently these were assurances which a Malaysian delegation to Peking did not get. The article went on:

quote.para: Because they felt that Australia's subsequent haste in recognising Peking made it more difficult for others to negotiate satisfactory terms for the establishment of diplomatic relations, some senior Malaysian ofncials have been extremely critical of Canberra. One used language that is stiU unprintable, even in this permissive age, in describing Australia's haste.

continue.para: Then he went on to say what I have said:

quote.para: The Indonesians, the Singaporeans and the Thais, who are in less of a hurry than Malaysia to come to terms with Peking, are also disturbed.

continue.para: So if we accept this—an d I believe we have to accept it; I believe it is a fact—w e find that the countries of South East Asia are still not convinced of Peking's intentions and are still not convinced that agreements such as the Five Power Arrangements and SEATO should not be maintained. I had hoped that the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) would make a foreign policy statement before this, but he is being rather coy about it, no doubt for very good reasons. I had hoped that we would have an opportunity of debating foreign policy in depth.

I support this motion for the reason that I believe it will be a grave mistake for Australia to withdraw its battalion from Singapore in view of the desire of the countries of South East Asia to retain that presence because of the obvious feeling of insecurity in the region and the feeling that they need to have there forces belonging to the Five Power Arrangements as an insurance and as a measure of stability. That is their view and I believe we should listen to it if we are to have a credible policy in Asia and any credibility in the region.

I do not believe that our relations with Thailand are as good as Senator Willesee told me yesterday, having regard to Mr Whitlam's gaffe recently. 1 think it was an extraordinary statement that Mr Whitlam made. It could have been made only by a man with an almost incredible ego. He was severely rebuked by the Deputy Foreign Minister of Thailand. The argument that the presence of foreign troops in Thailand would lead to another Vietnam—o r could lead to another Vietnam, I think he said, to be fair to him; I think he qualified it—seem s to me to be naive beyond reason. What comes first—the chicken or the egg? Has the communist insurgency in northern Thailand, in southern areas of Thailand and in the north of Malaysia been caused by the presence of American troops in Thailand? I do not think that anybody could argue that. Is this insurgency likely to be increased because of the presence of American troops in Thailand? I do not think anybody can argue that. I would be interested to hear arguments in support of such a contention. The Thais want American forces in their country because they have a feeling of instability as a result of these communistsupported insurgents. That is why I cannot understand Mr Whitlam's statement.

The Malaysians, with the exception of certain Air Force units, have no foreign troops in their country; yet they are suffering from an increased measure of insurgency. So I believe that the insurgency is still inspired. We can only hope that China has changed its mind and that it will gradually withdraw its support and encouragement from the insurgents. And when that day comes, I believe we shall have a very sound argument for withdrawing our troops and that the countries in the region would then wish us to withdraw our troops. So it depends on the policies of other countries.

I conclude by saying that I find it difficult to accept the argument raised by Senator Bishop in his wide-ranging statement that our relations with the United States are as good as ever. 1 think the incredible, vulgar and crude attack on the President of the United States by some of the honourable senator's colleagues has done nothing for Australia's relationship with the United States. And I believe that the attack by Mr Hartley and the Victorian socialist left on Mr Lee Kuan Yew, the democratic socialist, and the statement that Singapore is not a democratic State, bave done nothing but harm to our image in the region. I can only hope that the Government has conveyed privately to Mr Lee Kuan Yew—i t did not make a public statement— a message that it completely dissociates itself from the statement which was made and which undoubtedly received wide publicity.

It is on those grounds and those grounds only that I support the motion. I have some doubts as to the second part of the motion— I think it concerns a problem for the Labor Party—bu t I would certainly support the first part.

talk.start.para: -Senator Bishop,I think, has laid the foundation of the Australian Government's attitude to this question. We have heard a fair amount of loose talk. The more I look at the wild statements in the motion, the more I believe that they cannot possibly be backed by any debate or any facts that can be brought before the Senate. Since the advent of the Labor Government it has been made tremendously clear throughout the world that there has been a change in Australia's stance on foreign policy, and this has been welcomed throughout the world. The fact that we have moved from a military stance has been welcomed. When one considers the countries in our region that we are talking about one asks why, having regard to their size, geographic position and history, they would want any of their friends insisting on a completely military stance. That is the last thing they could possibly want.

speech.para: What has to be realised, and what is tremendously important, is that we have lost peace in this area on so many occasions that it will be a standing disgrace to the countries in the area if we ever lose it again. That is the tremendous challenge that faces not only Australia and New Zealand and the ASEAN countries but the countries outside the 2 blocs or sections that I have just mentioned. We lost peace in 1954, we lost a chance for peace again after the Korean war, and now we have this third opportunity which must not be lost. We lost peace twice in the field of military battle by insisting on the very things that the Democratic Labor Party and people like Senator Sim are insisting on tonight. That has led to failure. We are saying that it is time that another approach was made to this question. I do not think that either the DLP or those members of the Liberal Party whom I have heard speak on foreign affairs in the last 3 weeks realise the tremendous significance of the changes that have taken place in the world. They are still living in the cold war period when the 2 giants, the 2 super-powers, were glaring at each other across the globe. It was required of small nations and of middle sized nations to line up and be counted so that they were then on one side as the goodies or on the other side as the baddies. Thank heaven, that situation has changed.

We. have a situation in our area in which we do not have to look over our shoulder at Russia, or the United States of America. We have this multi-polar situation involving countries like the People's Republic of China, Japan, Russia, the USA and England. They are creating a multi-polar situation which gives within the region much more flexibility for countries such as our own, the Asian countries and the smaller countries throughout the world. It gives these countries, particularly in the region we are talking about tonight, much more manoeuvreability and much more flexibility.

The Indonesians summed it up by saying that national resiliance is needed. This means that each of these countries has to be put in a situation in which it can stand on its own feet and make its own arrangements or negotiations or in which these countries can combine and do these things which it had been impossible to do since the end of the last war. If you talk to the representatives of these people you find that they are trying to grab at the position with both hands. That is why we see a combination such as ASEAN that started off in a very tenuous situation. It has grown in confidence into a situation in which the countries talk together very much more freely and very much more boldly than I think even they dared to think about in the early stages of their formation.

The countries themselves are now talking about moving into a situation in which this organisation can embrace more people. Already they are looking to the forward situation in which they can take in the IndoChinese states and possibly Burma. They are not waiting for the Khmer Republic to join them. Its people are still not in a position to be talking like this. But the countries to which I have referred are throwing their arms wide open to receive, other countries. The challenge in this area is not the challenge of a thousand or so troops in Singapore. The great challenge in this area is, firstly, stability and, ultimately, peace. I suppose that 'peace* is a word similar to love in that it can be used in many ways. But we cannot get away from the fact that if ever we lose the peace in sufficiently large quantities, as we have, done in 2 world wars, there will never be any chance of rising from the degradation into which the whole world will be thrown again. It is stated in the motion that we will ultimately destroy the confidence of America. What we are talking about is the withdrawal of some troops - not all troops - from Singapore, perhaps 800 or 1,000 troops will be involved. The number of American troops in South Vietnam alone was 500.000. Do honourable senators opposite think that the Americans will quiver and quake because we make these arrangements because a sovereign government made it clear before it was ever elected that this is exactly what it would do? It becomes almost laughable when we start vo think about the situation.

What has happened under the previous Government and what has to be destroyed by this Government and by other governments that want to see peace in the world is the practice of drawing lines around the world and saying that a country on that side of the line is a baddie and a country on this side of the line is a goodie. We hear criticisms in the Senate day after day by way of questions because the Government has recognised the People's Republic of China and the Government of North Vietnam. The phrase we used to hear for years about the containment of China is the very sort of thing that causes war. Could any power in the world finally contain 700 million people on one land mass? The proposition was never a goer at any stage. It was able to take some credence during the cold war period. Of course the final situation is that the whole world has come to its senses.

When the Democratic Labor Party tries to blow up the fact that we are to reduce the number of troops in Singapore, the matter becomes a laughable proposition. Let honourable senators ask themselves for one moment: Would the ASEAN countries such as Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia. Thailand and the Philippines want Australia to be emphasising a military stance? None of them are great powers. Most of them are very small powers. Indonesia, because of its situation, its numbers, its tremendous wealth and the resilience of its people probably one day will become a great power. But most of the people sitting in the Senate chamber tonight will not be here when that takes place.

These countries are a combination of small powers. Why in the world would they want their friends to be emphasising a military stance? The very thing they fear is military action. They know perfectly well that if a world war were to break out and the great powers were to move on them they would be annihilated. See their actions are designed to create a detente in this area which will make such a development impossible. The Democratic Labor Party has said that withdrawing some of our troops will cause all the other countries in the world to collapse - that New Zealand, the United Kingdom and America will be affected. The fact is that Lord Carrington, after his trip to Australia, said in answer to a question in the British House of Commons that the Australians were going to withdraw some troops, that the British would maintain their level of troops and that New Zealand would do the same.

This has not been some sort of action taken off the top of our head. Our intention to take this action has been clearly demonstrated to the world, not over the last 6 months but over the 3 years before we were elected as a government. After we were elected as a government, we kept these countries fully informed of what we were doing. Because of that, there is no worry or kerfuffle in Great Britain, America or New Zealand. The contents of this motion and the whole of the way in which the members of the Democratic Labor Party and the Liberal Party talk indicate that all our relationships with these countries are based on military might - as though we have a great military might. What military might have we compared to countries such as Russia, China, the United States of America and Great Britain?

DLP senators speak as if this represents the whole of our relationship with these countries. The fact is that defence aid is being given and will continue to be given to these countries. We have a co-operative system operating with these people. We are giving them technical assistance. We are acting in advisory situations and carry out joint exercises. We give them logistic support. Above all, we give aid which is much more beneficial and which is one of the greatest things that we do because of the number of people who train in Australia. This hierarchy of people who have trained in Australia move through the whole of the public service and the business community of Asian countries. For years, we have had 1,000 students from Singapore in Australia. At the moment, we have 6.000 Malaysian students in Australia. If discussions are held with representatives of departments in these countries, it will be found that you do not have to go very far down the line until you strike somebody who has taken a degree in Australia. Generally, the person will have attended a university in Melbourne or Sydney and, probably more than any other place, the university in Perth because of its accessibility to these people.

Our aid to Malaysia alone is worth $30m. In Indonesia, you do not have to travel very far before you find aid of the first magnitude being carried out efficiently. The whole of the telephone system in Indonesia has been updated over the last 12 months under the supervision of an Australian Post Office engineer. Work on the Bogor water supply scheme is under the charge of Australian engineers. We have put in the minimum support, letting the people in the country do the work. We give advice and the initial aid. Do not honourable senators think that this aid is more important than military aid? They should not talk about a military presence in such countries when the very thing they fear is military action.

Twice Australian troops have marched away to the other side of the world to support Great Britain in times of war. There was never any question, either before World War 1 or in between the 2 world wars where the sympathies of Australia lay. But did Australia have 1,000 troops based on the Isle of Wight, on the Isle of Man or in the south of England? Did we demand that those troops should be there to show that we were true? What difference would it make in the event of an armed attack? At the time that the Liberal-Country Party Government sent troops to Singapore, we were told in answers to questions and in a statement made by Mr Gorton who was the Prime Minister at the time that they were not there to stand up to military aggression from outside. Certainly, they were not there to deal with any internal aggression that could be a nationalistic movement. This remains the $64 question: What the devil were they doing there, if this is the situation? The Five Power Arrangements do not require that we should have troops in these areas. What these countries want and what they will get is the number of troops to do those things about which we have talked. lt has been mentioned that we are going to throw these people into peril. What sort of peril is involved when we are talking about withdrawing merely a handful of troops? The whole military stance is one that ought to be reversed and it is one that these countries welcome our reversing. We heard criticism when in the very early days of this Government we stopped throwing military aid into South Vietnam and there was a great cry to heaven. We were sending military aid into an area which was saturated with military aid; the people in the area could not use any more of the aid. The previous Government was withdrawing troops from South Vietnam, saying that it was trying to wind the war down, but at the same time it was sending military aid to South Vietnam. This motion is in some ways analogous to that. The Democratic Labor Party says that it wants troops in this area. Why? In case there is going to be a world war in which we all will be involved? In case there is going to be some internal insurrection, which the troops would not engage in anyway, because that is the sort of thing in which other countries will not get involved in the future?

We are building up relationships by providing aid. In one year 6,000 students from one country and 1,000 students from another, who had been studying in Australia, returned to their own countries as the greatest ambassadors which Australia could send into these areas. These are continuing and lasting things. Tonight Senator Sim said: 'I do not believe that the five power pact is going to be of any permanency'. Whatever one might say about Senator Sim, one cannot say really that he is such a great radical. He said that statements made by some people in Australia irrevocably destroy our relationships with other countries. I remember criticism being levelled about 2 Manchester Jews. I assure the Senate that that did not destroy any relationship between Great Britain and Australia: it did not destroy any relationship between Manchester and Australia, and it did not destroy anything between Israel and Australia. In fact, it turned out that they were not Jews anyway. Senator Sim refers to a statement made by somebody and says that it destroys our relationship with another country. He can say these things, but I assure him, in case he feels uneasy about it, that the statement he made did not worry Manchester, it did not worry Israel and it did not really worry Australia. If you get these things into perspective you can see just how ridiculous one can get.

What does the Democratic Labor Party expect? Does it expect that because we have stationed troops in another country, like the laws of the Medes and the Persians the position can never be altered; that there have to be X troops stationed in Singapore; that there have to be so many Mirages stationed in Malaysia; and that this is the way it has got to remain forever? It is because of this cold war attitude and because of the implacable, old fashioned attitudes that are inherent in this motion tonight that you have your Vietnams and your Koreas. Surely we realise today that because of the atomic bomb the possibilities of such wars are thus far diminished. Having reached this situation, what is to happen next? Do we want to go on with all these old military postures? I have heard the previous Government sabre rattling at Russia - a country of 245 million people, with one of the great land masses in the world, and spending more on a percentage basis on its military commitments than any other country. Australia with a population of 13 million people and spending a very small proportion of its income on military commitments is rattling a sabre at these people. That was the problem with the previous Government which unfortunately was backed by the DLP. I say 'unfortunately' because it could have had a balancing influence on the government of the day but very obviously it is going the full way in the field of foreign policy in a cold war atmosphere.

Why does the DLP adopt this attitude? As I say, it is just leading on, not moving one bit away from the former situation. If there is one place in the world where you ought to be able to feel the change it is the South East Asian area. This is why we have an interest in this area. This is why almost weekly since the advent of this Government topline people have been coming from all around the world to visit Australia. You name the country and they are coming from it to Australia. If the members of the DLP are going to be blind to the changes that have taken place in this area, they will do so at their own peril. Firstly, they do not realise that colonialism died in South East Asia following the war. Every one Df the countries about which we are talking, except Thailand, has been under foreign control at some time or another, and the scars of it are fading slowly. At long last the People's Republic of China is being recognised by the world. It is coming out of its cocoon, and it was largely that country's own fault for being in that position. Japan is now one of the great, aggressively commercial countries. At long last the Vietnam war has finished. We will have to pour tens of millions of dollars of aid not into building up any regime but into patching up the wounded, putting them into hospitals where many of them will remain for the rest of their lives. We have to overcome the effects of carpet bombing and give light shelter in order to keep these people away from the elements. Basically this is how we have to move on our own in the Indio-China area. The situation in the Indo-China area, as far as Australia is concerned, will be just that. We are not going to be concerned whether the type of government of the man who is lying in hospital is a communist government or a right wing government or whether it is going to be some form of a coalition government. The person is going to be a person. It he needs aid, then to the limited extent that Australia can give it, we will do so. The amount of our aid is not great when it is compared with the aid given by the great powers. But we are going to be in there doing our little bit in order to establish that as a wealthy country in this area we do care, not about the regimes but about the people and the things that we can do for them.

Honourable senators opposite are talking tonight as though all of the Asian countries are standing back, glaring at us with hatred. The fact is that they are agreeing with everything we do. They are talking about a zone of peace, freedom and security. We have told them God bless them, that we are with them 100 per cent of the way in their desire to bring that about. We are doing it not by interfering with them but by saying: 'Here is a fairly wealthy country that is slightly different from you, but we are in your area and we are here to assist and see that this happens, because if you go back to your Koreas or your Vietnams you may never get another chance for peace in this area.' This is the third time around and it must not be allowed to fail. These are the aspirations of these countries and these are the aspirations that we are supporting.

It has been said that Indonesia's confidence will be destroyed if we take some troops out of Singapore. Let us think about that for a moment. Indonesia is a country of 120 million people who are shying away even at this stage from military pacts and who at long last have moved cautiously into co-operation with their neighbours. It is said that if we take 800 or 1,000 troops out of Singapore and bring them back to Australia this will destroy the confidence of Indonesia in Australia. Why we waste time in debating things such as this just beats me. The fact is that, excepting New Guinea, Indonesia is receiving more aid from Australia than any other country to which we are sending aid. We are working with Indonesia on defence co-operation. We are giving that country economic and technical aid. At the end of Mr Whitlam's visit to Indonesia, the President of Indonesia thanked Mr Whitlam for the exchanges of ideas and stated that what Mr Whitlam was talking about in the area was the very thing that Indonesia wanted. Then they come back to America again because this is the emotional issue. This is the follow-up. The previous Government got itself into trouble time and again, ably aided and abetted by the Democratic Labor Party, because at no stage did it examine the field of foreign affairs to see what should be done. it looked at foreign affairs and said: How can we win votes within Australia?' That Government finished up being the laughing stock of the world. It was dragged into Vietnam because its great partner, America, decided that it should go in. There was no other reason. We could never get the reason, but it stood out like a sore thumb that that was the reason.

It has been up to this Government to state clearly and concisely the things we stand for. The fact that we have said that racialism has no part in our foreign policy has brought us friends throughout the Asian and African countries that we have not known for 25 years. We have heard a lot of claptrap here tonight. The fact is that Senator Gair's motion can be dismissed as old-fashioned scaremongering based on a completely unreal view of what the situation is throughout the whole of South East Asia. The Opposition parties do not realise the changes that have taken place. I suppose a couple of generations of Australians have been brought up hearing, as I did when I was a child, about the British

Fleet. I did not know what it meant, but if anything happened the British Fleet would be there. The fact is that the only time Britain did try to help us with its fleet was at a time when Britain herself was heavily over committed and she sent the 'Prince of Wales' and the 'Repulse' and they never fired a shot. This was the myth.

talk.start.para: They did not have to, did they?

Mr Deputy President, you can see how difficult it is. Two ships went down in a completely normal nava] action as a result of fighter planes coming out in the normal formation and sinking them, and Senator Webster says that they did not have to fire a shot. That was their idea. They never fired one. This is not criticism of England. I give her full marks for bending over backwards to do what she did. I am saying that the whole of that era was a myth. We said that because there was a British fleet in those years and because we had a great power with us we had no worries. Then our eyes turned towards America, and we said that no matter what we did America would be there. There is no God given right to be able to look forward at what a military situation will be or to see whether we can depend on any of our friends. The fact today is that there is no longer a cold war. There is no longer a situation in which we are lined up and have to look at 2 countries. We have to look in this area at the power of the United States, the power of Great Britain, and ultimately the power of China, Japan and Russia. These are all great powers and it is of no use poking our tongue out at them and saying to them: 'If you do anything we wili rouse at you and send you a protest note or something.' These are the realities of the situation in which we live, and if we do not face up to the realities of the situation with respect to our neighbours and the world we will be left for dead. It is of no use the Opposition trying to draw in its mind the picture that it wants. The Government has been criticised because it recognised North Vietnam. We recognised North Vietnam becaase it is a reality.
- It is a communist country.
Wha t did Thailand say about Mr Whitlam?
- What did Mr Malik say.

I am getting several interjections from these great experts so can I have them one at a time? Let me deal with Senator Webster's interjection first. He said: 'What did Thailand say about Mr Whitlam?' Precisely nothing. We have not had one word of complaint from Thailand in any of the cables from Thailand which I read every day. That is the situation, but the honourable senator in his narrow way of trying to fight the whole of our foreign policy on the basis of softie article he read in an Australian newspaper reporting what was said in a Thai newspaper, says that that is what all the Thais think about Mr Whitlam. Believe me, there is no country in the world which will not let us know very quickly whether it likes something we do or dislikes something we do. There has been not one word of protest from Thailand about an article that appeared in 'Newsweek'. What was that situation? It was not a criticism of Thailand. Mr Whitlam was asked for an opinion dealing with the whole of the region and he expressed the worry that if troops stayed in Thailand we might create a Vietnam situation.
- What did the Deputy Foreign Minister say about Mr Whitlam?
Th e one who was here the other day? Senator Webster refers to the Deputy Foreign Minister but I do not know which one he is talking about. There are several hundred of them in the world.
- Of Thailand.

Ther e has been, I repeat, no official complaint from Thailand about Mr Whitlam. That is the fact. I know it is not the fact which the honourable senator wants but what I am trying to get him to do is look at the facts and then to base foreign policy on them instead of trying to use smear tactics and doing things merely to get votes because that is where the previous Government made itself the laughing stock of the world. We get the old communist smear and the smearing of people merely because honourable senators opposite do not like the Government. We have had suggestions that We should not trade with communist countries but those who make those suggestions do not worry about the human situation. What we have here tonight, of course, is a political stunt and honourable senators opposite perfectly well know it. There is not one bit of analysis in what has been put here, not one bit of it. It is nonsense to say that Indonesia is worried because we are taking troops out of Singapore; that America is going to quake because while she takes half a million people out of Vietnam we are taking 800 out of Singapore; that America is terribly worried that the 800 will affect the half a million.

continue.para: There is nothing which ought to be debated on a higher level in this Parliament than the whole field of foreign policy. But the Opposition continually drags it down and refuses to face up to the situation. It moves motions like the one before us and wastes the time of the Senate because it bogs the Senate down, and does so in order that it can go out and say in the crummy little newspapers that will back it, that there was another victory and another blow to the Labor Party. In doing so it makes itself the laughing stock of the world. The Government was criticised, and honourable members opposite made a lot out of it, because we protested to America over the bombing. But there was not one word from honourable members opposite that the unamimous decision of the Canadian Parliament was exactly the same as ours. That decision was made in the Canadian Parliament because there are parliamentarians in Canada who are broad enough to look at the world situation and are not worried about doing some cheap political stunting as the Opposition is trying to do tonight.

I have not bothered to read the motion aloud because it will be apparent to anybody who has a look at it that there is not one ounce of analysis in it. It is merely scaremongering. If honourable members opposite want to criticise on a high base something which the Government has done, I would be the first to debate it and the first to confess if there was some weakness in what we did because there is nothing we do in life which is perfect. There will always be rubs, and when we are dealing in this field of foreign affairs we are dealing in the most sensitive area that the whole of Government policy can bring about. In domestic policy we can do what we like. This situation has been likened to having a ship at sea where one can go where one likes—forward , back, drop anchor, stop and fish and do what one likes. But in the field of foreign policy, the ship is in a river which has a narrow channel, and there are other ships around and a bank on either side, and every time that the ship moves we are inclined to affect the others. If only we would remember that.

Mr Deputy President, the Government Whip is telling me that I should wind up and I will be glad to do that. I merely repeat that the motion before us tonight is a repetition of the cold war thesis that the Government and the Democratic Labor Party have lived on for so long. There is no analysis in the motion of the situation. It is mere scaremongering: it is mere smearing: it is merely using foreign policy to do some little thing which the Opposition feels may win it one or two votes throughout Australia. Last night Senator Wheeldon put his finger right on it when he said: 'You are many years out of date. The stunt you tried last night will not pay off'. We live in a much more enlightened Australia and a much more enlightened world today. Such tactics will simply fail. 1 offer one word of advice to honourable senators opposite. They had better get down to being dinkum about things. They had better get down to having a look at what foreign policy is all about and stop using it for political stunting within Australia.

talk.start.para: - -It is greatly to be regretted that the Special Minister of State (Senator Willesee) should have seen fit to claim that the very mild, very sane and very rational motion proposed by the Australian Democratic Labor Party is nothing more than a political stunt. There was only one of all his remarks with which I could agree, that is, that there are very few areas of discussion which occupy more of the time of this Parliament than the area of foreign affairs and defence. As honourable senators know, the Democratic Labor Party has always elevated these matters into the forefront of national consideration. We have taken our stand on them even at times when to do so was not popular. The Democratic Labor Party has often taken a stand on policies because they were embedded in principles, although they were politically unpopular and unrewarding. We make no excuse for our continued defence of the situation in relation to Australia's involvement in the countries to our north west and north east. That is a strong policy; it is a clear policy; it is a consistent policy; it is a policy which we have always projected.

speech.para: The point at issue in this debate, as Senator Willesee indicated, is: 'What is the attitude of the nations in South East Asia to the Australian presence in that area?' Senator Willesee says that they do not want us there and that to suggest they do is merely an outmoded approach to foreign policy - a sort of nineteenth century neo-colonialism. 1 had the opportunity to be in that area about 18 months ago with a parliamentary delegation. We visited Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore. Everywhere we went we had high level discussions. We had discussions with General Nasution, with Lee Kuan Yew, with Tun Ismail, and with Adam Malik in Indonesia. Honourable senators will realise that I do not attribute to any one of those persons anything I might now say, because to do so would be a breach of faith. I am going to give to the Senate the composite, as I assessed it, of the concern of the leaders of those countries in relation to the vulnerability of the area and the significance of the Australian presence.

talk.start.para: Yo u once gave us a report on the elections over there and you were proved wrong.

That is completely untrue. I was proved completely and totally right. I will not be diverted in the few minutes at my disposal from putting my case. The parliamentary delegation spoke to all the leaders of those countries. It met the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Indonesian Parliament. Everywhere I went and had discussions during which I had the opportunity of asking questions I put the same question:- 'What is your attitude to the Australian presence in this area?' I came away with the firm conviction, on the evidence of the statements made lo me, that the Australian presence in Singapore and in the other areas is welcomed by al) those countries. What is the position in those countries? There is an instability in Malaysia because of the Malay-Chinese confrontation. Because there is an instability the Malaysians are vulnerable. It is said in Malaysia that if communism breaks through the Indo-Chinese peninsula it breaks through into Thailand. Chin Peng already has insurgents on the Thai-Malay border. If the insurgency breaks through the Thai-Malaysia border it is into Malaysia.
- Oh!

Senator Wheeldon says 'Oh!' as if that were some theory of my own. That is what I was told in those areas by the leaders of those nations. If insurgency breaks through into Malaysia it will move into Singapore. Indonesia has a similar problem. Because of the attempted coup there in 1965 there is still a political and social instability in the area. Indonesia has never known how far the communist penetration went, and is also vulnerable.

continue.para: Those nations all say: 'Australia's ptesence in our area is an identification of you; country with our welfare'. They plead: 'Give us time. We can hold back any threat to this area if we can strengthen our economy. If we can contain the threat at this moment, by our own strength and our own economic ability we will be able to contain any future threat. You are helping to buy us time because you are helping us to stabilise our economy'. That is the feature of the Australian presence there in their interests. We know the Australian presence has a great feature in our interests and a great significance from our point of view. But from their point of view it is absolutely inseparable from their continued stability and their ability to defend themselves in the future. To suggest, as Senator Willesee has suggested, that these people do not want us there is completely wrong. That has been completely denied by the statements made of the leaders of those countries and by their whole conduct and disposition towards the Australian presence in Singapore and Malaysia. For Senator Willesee to propound that proposition is to base a case on a totally false and indefensible premise, because the whole truth lies the other way. For those reasons the motion the Democratic Labor Party has brought forward is of very great importance and very great significance. It is time we had a definitive expression of opinion by the Senate on the subject. Therefore, I move:
That the question be now put.
