talk.start.para: - I find it imperative tonight to speak to the motion for the adjournment to draw the attention of the Minister for Primary Industry (Senator Wriedt) to the sad plight of the apple and pear industry in southern Tasmania, northern Tasmania and on the north west coast. The Australian Apple and Pear Board stated in its report for 1970-71 that there was little doubt that at the then rate of freight to Europe, all European trade was open to question. It said that the industry was therefore facing a most serious situation, which in realistic terms could involve the very survival of large sections of the industry. Although the stabilisation scheme that the Liberal-Country Party Government established enabled apple and pear growers, not only in Tasmania but in Australia generally, who shipped fruit on consignment to Europe to be paid $2.5m in 1971 and $3.1m in 1972, events have crowded in to create for the industry a handicap that must be taken into serious account. The first is that due to the revolution in shipping, freights in this industry have grown until now the effective freight rate is likely to be of the order of $3.7 a bushel.
What we want is our own fruit ships.

Th e Government cannot even float the 'Straitsman' to run from Melbourne to King Island. To talk about your own line of ships to carry our fruit from Hobart to London is simply a cranky suggestion. On Sundays waterfront labour alone requiries SI .02 a case to take fruit from the shed on the wharf to the ship. It costs 60c a case in ordinary time to shift it a matter of 50 yards from the shed to the ship. That is one of the areas in which the Government has a responsibility to give the industry something to offset the increase in freight.

continue.para: The second thing arises partly out of that. In the last few weeks there has been a surcharge on all export industry from Hobart due to a rearrangement of the levy that provides for permanent waterside worker costs. This increases the cost of those levies per man hour of waterfront labour from 40c a man hour to 85c a man hour. I come now to the third point. The Government has made a most inadequate contribution to redress the damage it has done to the industry. By revaluing unilaterally, as it did in December, it imposed on the industry a cost of probably 60c to 65c per case, thus depriving the owners of that degree of overseas price. On a very moderate crop of 10,000 cases, this would involve the grower in a loss of $6,000. Yet the pitiful pronouncement of the Government was that it would make a contribution per orchard not in excess of $1,500. It is implicit in the statement made by the Minister for Primary Industry that that is on a social service scale, not a commercial scale. The idea of the Labor Government was to punish the grower who had a sizable crop forgetting, of course, that in this indusiry wherever there is an orchard producing a large crop there is a commensurate number of employees. When the Government is punishing that power it is punishing his employees as well. I wanted to bring those factors about this industry to the Minister tonight because, knowing that a conference of Ministers involved is to be held tomorrow week, they can be seriously brought into the Ministers' assessment at that meeting.

I want to add that with the foresight that Sir John McEwen established in trade, realising the switch from the European market that was inevitable with the onset of the European Economic Community, we developed trade into the Pacific. That trade has expanded gradually and involves over a million cases through Singapore today. 1 believe that if we were to exert sufficient effort— I put this suggestion before my own Government while I was a Minister and I put it now in the same spirit of positive contribution to the present Government—w e could overcome the objections that Japan has to allowing access for our fruit. As honourable senators know, that is based upon the quarantine objection that, according to the Japanese, we have codlin moth in this country. I do not see why we should not have an equally powerful campaign to suppress codlin moth as we have undertaken against tuberculosis and brucellosis in cattle. I urge that suggestion to the Minister so that we can all take it up without trying to score points from each other on questions of politics. If we could only persuade Japan to accept our fruit we would have a northern hemisphere market in the season when our fruit is available for export shipping which, 1 believe, would take up the handicap of the loss of the English markei. I hope that together we can do something to rescue this really wonderful industry.

talk.start.para: - 1 think that for the first time I am transgressing on the motion for the adjournment of the Senate.and for that reason I think that Senator Mulvihill should remain and listen to me. I want to refer to a statement which appeared today in the Hobart 'Mercury'. Although I do not always agree with the man who made the statement I believe it is correct. He said that the apple industry in Tasmania had reached its moment of truth. An industry that is worth $15m to a small State like Tasmania with a population of 300,000 people is well worth preserving. It is the biggest primary industry we have in that State. It has been struggling for many years against the gravest financial difficulty and I believe that the Government's revaluation has just about put the cap on the whole financial aspect of the apple industry in Tasmania. I remember when New Zealand and the United Kingdom both devalued. The then Department of Trade and Industry estimated that that was the equivalent of a 20 per cent reduction in the Australian tariff. Such a view did the then Government take of the position that some primary industries were compensated on that account because of the intense competition and because of the difficulties experienced in exporting primary products to the United Kingdom.

speech.para: Now this currency change is working the other way. This Government has revalued and it has placed a burden on everything that ;s exported from this country. I believe that unless some concrete assistance is brought to bear on this industry it will be the last straw that breaks the camel's back.

In the same newspaper in which Mr Brown, the secretary of the industry organisation, made these grim comments there appeared another statement which relates to a 25 per cent rise in the minimum basic wage. I am not arguing about that matter at all, but the statement went on to say that employers of men on the minimum wage will face a total extra wages bill of S200m a year. The newspaper article states:

quote.para: Federal Cabinet has decided that the Government will join with the ACTU in pressing for a 25 per cent increase in the minimum wage.

speech.para: The Government is favourable to that proposition and will join with the Australian Council of Trade Unions in pressing for it. This article continues:

quote.para: This would increase the minimum wage from the present average of SSI. 80 to $65 a week.

speech.para: I conclude by saying that nearly all of these costs, if not all of them, must be met ultimately from the pockets of the producers. This additional impost and all the other imposts on the community, if they are not met in a more generous manner than that detailed by Senator Wright, will spell the end of the apple industry in Australia. I often look around the Huon Valley and the. Tamar Valley at the closer settlement, the homesteads, the buildings and the people who have gathered there. As far as I know they are living happy lives. Imagine what would happen to those areas if anything drastic happened to this industry. The Government holds the purse strings for the whole Commonwealth. It apparently proposes to go to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and press for a $200m a year increase in the wage bill. As far as the apple industry is concerned the Government should come to life and make the industry a viable proposition.

talk.start.para: - I do not wish to delay the Senate for any length of time but I do wish to make it quite clear that as another Tasmanian senator I join Senator Wright and Senator Lillico in expressing concern at the situation of the apple and pear industry in Tasmania. I do not suggest that the Minister for Primary Industry (Senator Wriedt) is unconscious of the problem but I do suggest that perhaps he may have some problems in being able to ileal with the situation adequately when the approach of the Government to the management of the economy is that a pittance shall be meted out - as if it were a social welfare payment - to an industry which is struck down as a result of an economic decision of the Government. I do not challenge that decision which related to revaluation. But as a result of that decision this industry was entitled to real consideration. Instead of that we have the sort of approach which is a social welfare approach.

speech.para: Almost within a week or so of that decision a decision was made to give 4 weeks annual leave to all Commonwealth public servants. I do not wish to be taken as suggesting in any way that Commonwealth public servants are not entitled to be well treated within the community - but I emphasise within the community'. Everyone knows that the 4 weeks annual leave given to public servants in this way will spread throughout general employment. But will it spread to primary industry, to the small self-employed man who has been struggling for years in Tasmania to keep his orchard going? He would like to get to the stage where he had to work only 80 hours a week - this situation applies to a lot of the orchardists. He would like to get to the stage where he would be able to look forward to having annual holidays and actually pay for them. But the Government has not adopted an attitude which is related to fair compensation for the disability suffered as a result of its acting in the interests of the overall population in making a revaluation. Instead of adequately compensating those who suffer it adopts a social service approach. If one can show that one has filed a bankruptcy petition one gets a pittance out of the Government.

The plight of the industry is such that I would imagine that Senators Devitt, Townley, Wriedt, Poke and O'Byrne would be prepared to join with the honourable senators who have already spoken tonight. I believe that this is a situation where the interests of a Slate are vitally concerned. The interests of a State, as represented by its honourable senators in this chamber, should be heard and should be met. I suggest that this is an occasion when those towns of the apple growing areas of Tasmania which honourable senators from Tasmania and many other honourable senators in this chamber know so well are under a threat of death. This could be overcome as a result of Government action but it will be brought to fruition as a result of Government inaction. Many things can be done. I shall not hold the Senate tonight. I simply express briefly the concern which I hold along with other Liberal senators from Tasmania.

I am sure that the other senators from Tasmania - if they are to be heard - will urge the Minister, who fortunately is a Tasmanian and no doubt has the interests of this Tasmanian industry at heart, to take adequate steps to prevent the sort of situation mentioned by Senator Wright, Senator Lillico and myself, from happening to these towns and people. There are many small, self-employed people. Sometimes they employ a few other people on their orchards for at least part of the year. They are providing employment and an income for themselves. They are keeping the rural towns going. They are keeping going the fabric of a society which has developed over a century. Very soon unless something happens this will be going for good.

talk.start.para: - As a Western Australian I cannot allow this debate to go on without a contribution on behalf of my State. I would hate to have a situation in which it was thought that only Tasmania had an apple and pear industry. The concern which has been expressed by the honourable senators from Tasmania is equally a concern in Western Australia. The apple growing industry is a major part of the economy of the south west of Western Australia. All the difficulties which have been mentioned and perhaps some more are experienced by those growers. We are fighting additional costs such as shipping and handling. The cost of packing is eating into the return to the grower so that he is always last on the list. Everyone else seems to be protected. The grower receives what is left.
That is not a new situation.

It is not a new situation. Just a few minutes ago my attention was drawn to a statement made by the Minister for Primary Industry (Senator Wriedt) in a speech to the Victorian Australian Labor Party Rural Conference in which he said:

quote.para: It is staggering to find that many, primary producers who voted for the Country Party each election expect me to solve their long-standing problems overnight; problems I inherited from the Country Party.

continue.para: I do not know whether he inherited the problems from the Country Party. I know that he inherited a problem of a fair economic distribution of the returns obtained by the people in the fruit growing industry, particularly the apple and pear industry. The Minister did not inherit the problem imposed by the Labor Government decision to revalue the Australian dollar. The Australian Country Party, as he knows very well, fought that imposition upon the export industries plus the added imposts and other matters which have already been raised by my Tasmanian colleagues. These are going to put an impossible burden upon the apple and pear industry unless, because of some fortuitous circumstances, the world price rises sufficiently to enable the growers to bear the burden. I believe that the recent rise in the prices of primary products throughout the world is the inevitable result of a process by which primary producers have been forced to accept the tail end of what is being charged to the consumers. Everyone else in the community is able to secure his return and simply deduct it from the amount being paid for the primary product.

There is an end to that process. That end results in a reduction of production so that the world suddenly finds itself without primary products. Unless we ensure that protection is given to the primary producers by means of legislation or by some other means which are not available in the ordinary economic processes, the situation will be aggravated and tbere will be real starvation in the world. Those who have smugly looked upon the people who are producing food as an inconsequential lot of hillbillies or the mugs of the economic scene will have a very rude awakening. When we read that Senator Wriedt has said 'We do not want the rural sector to become one vast sheltered region, soaking up scarce public funds that could be better spent on schools, hospitals and other vital community services that benefit both the country and city dweller', we can only think that he must have been reading the 'Australian Financial Review'.

talk.start.para: - I very much regret that I was not aware - I do not blame anybody for this - that it was proposed to launch, at this late stage of the proceedings, a debate on an important question such as this. For reasons of which 1 am not aware at the moment, I was not informed of this proposal. As I say, I acknowledge that it is not necessary for an honourable senator to inform another honourable senator that he intends to speak about a particular matter in the adjournment debate, but surely one would expect that as a matter of common courtesy an honourable senator who rises in his place and challenges other honourable senators to respond - a taunt, as it were - would, in the normal course of events, have given some forewarning. I think the rules of a fair fight normally demand that one at least gives one's opponent some forewarning so that he does not have his hands in his pockets or something like that.
Yo u should know all about these problems without making excuses.

Indeed I do, and that is what I intend to talk about. I will not say, as the Leader of the Country Party said in a similar situation some time ago, that people in difficulty in the rural industries should apply for social service benefits. I do not intend to say that and I do not think Senator Wriedt said that. I hope that he did not say it, because I think it is a studied insult to the people in the rural communities of Australia. Do not let us hear any nonsense about that. Senator Webster should check the record to see whether the Minister in the previous Government made some observations to the effect that people who got into difficulty in rural industries should apply for social service benefits. Do not let it be said that the Labor Party will descend to that level of debate.
- They would get a handout

speech.para: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Brown) - Order! Senator Webster, I have asked you on 3 occasions in the last 3 minutes to refrain from interjecting. I will ask you again to allow Senator Devitt to be heard without these constant interjections.

talk.start.para: Than k you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Perhaps I should modify the tone of my delivery, but I have been stung into responding to some of the observations which have been made by honourable senators. I heard some of them before I came into the chamber just by chance and some of them I have caught since I arrived in the chamber. One would think, to hear the observations of honourable senators who so far have expressed themselves on this matter, that suddenly as from 2nd December 1972 the rural industries of Australia have been plunged into a situation of economic difficulty. That is far from the case. I know this because I went through the situation myself. I actually experienced the situation under a Liberal-Country Party government and I know. I worked the hours which have been mentioned in this place.

continue.para: I certainly worked those hours and the returns were pretty small. But do not let us get carried away with the idea that this situation suddenly has arrived upon the appointment of the new Minister for Primary Industry (Senator Wriedt), a man who will turn out to be one of the best Ministers for Primary Industry that this country has had. This is already being acknowledged in rural sectors of the Australian economy. He has only just assumed this office and had had no experience whatsoever in it before. Do not let us get carried away with the idea that the problems exist only in the apple and pear industry and are related only to Tasmania. We have already had an acknowledgment from Senator Prowse that similar problems exist in Western Australia. I am not denying the right of honourable Senators from Tasmania to raise these matters, but some of my colleagues from Tasmania suddenly have developed a tremendous interest in the apple and pear industry. In a similar atmosphere to that which prevailed last night in relation to another matter I just make the simple observation, as a simple senator in this place, that the problems of this industry did not suddenly arise. They are of a very complex nature and solutions are not easy. I should think that the happiest man in this Senate would be a Minister for Primary Industry who had no problems in primary industry. To suggest that these suddenly have arisen because a member of this place has assumed the responsibility for that portfolio is absolute nonsense. We all know that, so let us acknowledge it.

What is the situation in relation to other areas of primary industry? I have tried desperately since I have been a member of the Senate estimates committee which is looking into the problems of primary industry and a number of aspects of primary industry to find out—an d I will pursue this line in the future—wh y it is that we are not able to assess for more than 5 months ahead what the market position is likely to be in relation to various forms of primary industry. In the computer age, in an age of technology and in an age of highly developed science it is not possible to do this. I have questioned this. 1 have gone into it quite deeply. I have sought the advice and help of experts in the field. I find—an d they acknowledge this—tha t because of the complex nature of world markets, because of climatic conditions and because of demands here and there, of one kind or another, it is just not possible to assess markets in the future.

Surely honourable senators must remember about 2 years ago the then Minister for Primary Industry saying to the dairy farmers of Australia: 'Look, this position is crazy. If you think this Government is going to go on subsidising the dairying industry in this way if it continues to develop in the way it is developing now, you have another think coming because the Government is not going to do it.' Remember what happened within a few short months. Overseas buyers were coming to Australia seeking further supplies of butter fat and further supplies of cheese with which to supply the markets of the world. It is not a new situation at all but is one that is being treated with great sensitivity by the present Minister for Primary Industry. The Minister has a great understanding of this problem. He wants to see this section of the economy put on a sound basis. I know Tasmania; I know it only too well. In fact, in my first speech in this place I spoke at great length on the problems of primary industry and related them fairly particularly to the situation as 1 knew it to exist, and as I had experienced it, in my own State of Tasmania. We have problems of marketing which are perhaps greater than those of some other States because we have a barrier which adds to our costs.

talk.start.para: - Do you think primary producers are having a bonanza?

Senator Wright, you have had one go. Please let me have mine. I would have thought that you would do me the courtesy of letting me know you were going to launch this debate on the apple and pear industry, because I am just as interested in it as you are. Indeed, Mr Acting Deputy President, I am perhaps more interested than the honourable senator is because more people in Tasmania support my Party than the Party to which he belongs. Perhaps I have a greater regard for and a greater interest in this matter than the honourable senator has, if one comes down to the numbers of people who have voted for the parties. Let us acknowledge that a great part of the State of Tasmania was built initally on the pome fruits industry—the apple and pear industry. It is my fervent hope and wish that circumstances will arise that will assist this industry to continue its operations in the future so that those people who depend upon it will be able to maintain their existence. This industry faces a tremendously difficult problem. Anybody who has had any association whatsoever with primary industry will know that the growing of apples and pears is carried out on areas of, say, 30 to 40 acres. That would be a fairly substantial area. If we phase this industry with its high capitalisation—buildings , machinery, plant and all the rest—ou t of existence, can anybody suggest what a grower would do with 30 to 40 acres? This is the problem that arises when we try to rationalise the whole approach to this industry.

continue.para: It has been my view for a long while, and nobody has yet persuaded me to the contrary, that one of the problems about this industry has been the nature of the pursuit and establishment of markets. One realises that of 3,000 million in the world today 2,000 million are not getting enough to eat, and when one considers the quality of and the benefit to be derived from the produce of this area of primary industry in Australia, one would expect that a government conscious of its responsibilities would have pursued with far greater vigour than it did the markets of the world so that the people in those markets would have an opportunity to buy this fruit and so lift their standard of living. I think that the pursuit of markets so that our fruit can be sold competitively against the products of other countries and so that people in those areas may buy them and thus help sustain themselves is of great importance. We are confronted with the results of inaction on the part of the former Government. To argue that honourable senators on only one side of this chamber have a concern for the rural industries of Australia is a pretty specious argument, to say the least. We have a very great concern indeed for every section of the Australian community be they in the cities or in the rural areas and I believe this has been forcefully demonstrated not only in the national sense but also in the States.

Revaluation has caused a great deal of concern, I know, not only to the primary industries in the production of foodstuffs but also in the mining industry. But does anybody in this chamber seriously suggest that revaluation was not very necessary. I think it was. I think the financial situation had reached the stage where fairly desperate action had to be taken. The Minister for Primary Industry, as I have observed in the 3 weeks of the current sitting, has consistently risen in his place and indicated that the Government, and particularly he himself as the Minister for Primary Industry, is prepared to listen to any reasonable argument to put industries on a proper economic basis following revaluation. He has in fact gone further than that and has invited sections of primary industry to make their representations to him. This question requires most sympathetic and sensitive treatment. As a Tasmanian I deplore the fact that the plight of this section of the rural economy of Tasmania has been used as a political argument when the whole question relates to the economics of the industry.

So I say that we have to go beyond the present concept of the solution to the problems of these industries. They are great and vast problems. I hope that there is a future for the apple and pear industry. The production of apples in Tasmania is the major part of the production in Australia. I acknowledge that Western Australia and South Australia play a role in it. But considering the relatively small population of Tasmania, this industry in Tasmania comprises a far greater part of the total economy of that State than it does in the larger States of South Australia and Western Australia which also grow apples. Let us get away from the political considerations and let us get down to the economic considerations of the matter.

talk.start.para: - It is typical of the honourable senators who raised this matter without advising other honourable senators that they were raising the matter that they should try to take advantage of the misfortune of the Tasmanian orchardists to score a miserable political point. The point is that the orchardists have had 23 years of misgovernment at a Federal level.
An d in the State. Admit that.

Of course the honourable senator must know that the State is a mendicant State. One of the reasons why it is a mendicant State is that federally it was disadvantaged by the policy of the Federal Government. The sheer hypocrisy of Senator Wright, an former Minister of the Crown
- 1 take a point of order. Mr President, it is offensive to me to hear Senator O'Byrne refer to the hypocrisy of one of my colleagues. The word 'hypocrisy' is offensive.
Th e point having been taken, this word is known to be so notoriously unparliamentary that it should be quashed at once. I ask that it be withdrawn.
I withdraw it, Mr President, and say that I am not sure whether it is Jekyll or Hyde who has been taking charge, but it is one or the other.
- 1 ask the impudent senator to withdraw that offensive statement.
Which one will I withdraw?
Is that personally offensive to you, Senator?
- You may judge it by your own standards, sir.
Senator O'Byrne, Senator Wright does not like being described in that way.
I will ask the schizophrenic senator to listen to me for a little while.
Wil l you withdraw the reference to Jekyll and Hyde and then go on?

I will withdraw the Jekyll but he has a lot of hide at times. This is too serious a matter for interjections, Mr President. The whole point is that the industry, as we all admit, is very sick. It will gain no advantage whatever from the grandstanding we have seen tonight from both Senator Rae and Senator Wright. There is no doubt that this Government is genuinely trying to lift the industry out of the mire into which it has sunk over the last 20 years.
- And the whole of primary industry.

Fortunately , other sections of primary industry—b y circumstances, by design or by act of God, with improving seasons and prices—ar e seeing a little bit of daylight. We cannot claim all the credit for that, but we are very pleased to see a situation in which at last the wool industry is getting out of the doldrums, the wheat industry can now get on with the job of increasing the quotas and can see future markets, and so on through the whole spectrum of primary industry. But the apple and pear industry in Tasmania, no doubt, is depressed. The previous Government has to bear the full responsibility for this industry being in its present plight. It has known, since the closure of the Suez Canal and since the first indications that Great Britain was to enter the European Economic Community, that the industry would face this problem with its traditional European and United Kingdom markets. Also, the decision on revaluation, for which this Government has been blamed, was up for discussion well before 2nd December. We had the spectacle of the previous Prime Minister, Mr William McMahon, and the Leader of the Country Party, Mr Anthony, conducting unseemly arguments to such an extent that the newspapers reported that the Leader of the Country Party would resign if the Liberal Party policy on revaluation of the Australia dollar were carried out. Tonight we are witnessing 2 Liberal Party senators trying to contradict the very position that their previous leader took on this matter.

continue.para: Senator Wriedt has stated repeatedly in the Senate that the Government will do whatever it can to help the Industry. I would like to give some advice to Senator Wright and some of his Tasmanian colleagues. What the industry needs is organised marketing. I know very well that Senator Wright has tramped the country, to my knowledge, for 20 years, and probably longer than that, with his old deadbeat, worn out, conservative ideas about the freedom of private enterprise. He has treated the orchardists like mushrooms. He has kept them in the dark—an d honourable senators know the other things. These people have never been able to see daylight because the forwarding agents, the shipping agents and all the other people have been on their backs while their political leaders at the Federal level have kept them in the dark. The Labor Government has been in office for only 100 days, but honourable senators opposite have the temerity to blame the plight of this industry on us.

talk.start.para: - The Government has done a lot of other things fairly quickly. When will it do something about this? Just say when it will do something about it.

The Minister for Primary Industry will reply to this debate. He has shown repeatedly his interest in the position of the Tasmanian orchardists. He realises that it is a very difficult situation which has been degenerating for a great number of years. The previous Government took the stand of introducing the tree-pull scheme is just the same way as it was responsible for the practical ibolition of the berry fruits industry. It allowed that magnificent, exclusively Tasmanian industry to go practically out of existence. It allowed one of our biggest fruit users, H. Jones and Co. Pty Ltd to slowly transfer its interests to South Africa where it was able to exploit the cheap labour and gain access to the European market in competition with Tasmanian fruit. But this is private enterprise and the whole set-up of the private entrepreneur. He does not care about orchardists; he cares about his profits. This company, which has been on the backs of the orchardists for so long, is repaying 99c in the dollar to its shareholders while the people who have been battling on for so long are in this plight.

continue.para: I draw attention to Senator Wright's reference to the workers in Tasmania. After 23 years, at long last they are starting to get their share of some of the prosperity evidenced in the reports and balance sheets of companies such as A. G. Webster and Woolgrowers Ltd, the Farmers and Graziers Cooperative Society Ltd and Henry Jones and Company. With the bonuses and profits that they are making, why should not all the employees get a reward for their year's work by getting 4 weeks annual leave? The type of attack that was made on the workers of Tasmania is reprehensible, to say the least. Rather than use the Senate as a forum for trying to make political capital, honourable senators opposite should be directing their minds and consciences back to the very poor efforts that they made during the many years when they had control of the Treasury bench and the machinery which could have helped these people instead of leaving them in the plight which they were in. They should not accuse us of being responsible for the position, in the short time that we have had to try to right the wrongs, and they should not say that we have failed. I believe that our policy will be of much greater advantage to the ochardists of Tasmania than was the policy of the previous Government.

talk.start.para: - Senator Wright advised me of his intention to speak on this matter tonight, but I confess that I did not envisage that it would develop into this rather lengthy debate at this hour of the night. I thank particularly Senator Devitt and Senator O'Byrne because their comments have covered most of the points. I agree that what has been said tonight by Senator Wright. Senator Rae and perhaps to a lesser extent Senator Lillico, was nothing more than an attempt to make cheap political capital out of a difficult situation which was inherited by this Government. Listening to Senator Wright, one would imagine that the Government was on trial. For his information, in the 1971-72 year in Tasmania the negative net income for fruit growers was $900 for the industry. Was this the result of 23 years of Liberal government? Is this the reason why the Government or I should be on trial after 4 months? Does he imagine that I will solve this problem in that time?
Ho w much time have we got?

Does Senator Townley imagine that by some act of melodrama I will come into the Senate and solve the problem? If that is the way that Senator Townley expects me to operate, I can assure him that I will not operate that way. I would much prefer to spend my time thinking my way carefully through this problem to see how I can overcome it. 1 will not do it and I will not try to do it in 5 minutes. This industry has had these problems for the past 10 years. I was in the industry. I know something about this aspect of primary industry, despite the fact that Senator Wright said earlier today that [ know nothing about primary industry. I am not particularly concerned about that.
- I did not make such a statement.

You said that 1 knew nothing about primary industry. I am not concerned about that because I do not place much value on his judgment anyway. I had some experience of this industry. In the late 1950s when 1 left it, all the writing of what eventually happened was on the wall. I can distinctly remember discussing this problem with a man who was in the industry at the same time. He got out of it when I got out of it, for the same reason: Nothing was being done to provide for the eventualities which had to come—the shrinking markets, the increase in the proportion of shipping costs, and also the fact that at the national level guidance was not being given to that industry to enable it to compete on world markets which were becoming increasingly competitive. We were slipping behind countries such as South Africa and the Argentine in our marketing methods—the very point that Senator O'Byrne and Senator Devitt made. These are the areas in which the previous administration could have taken the initiative and given a guide to these people as to what they might have done. Instead, we have to witness the spectacle of Tasmanian senators using this as a means of, I suppose, some election value in an election year when both Senator Wright and Senator Rae come up for election.

continue.para: I just wish to repeat the fact that 1 am not going to make any hasty judgment on this question, i want to see a viable industry in Tasmania— I am sure we all do—bu t Tasmania has problems which are peculiar to the island. Senator Devitt made the point that because of the small holdings the alternatives open to these people are limited. We can only restructure the industry along sound lines, which means particularly balancing production against our marketing outlets.

talk.start.para: - You are relying on grubbing grants, are you?

Senator Wright's Government introduced the scheme, and I must differ with him again. I believe that this was a positive scheme which Senator Wright's Government introduced, as 1 said in answer to a question in this chamber about 2 weeks ago. These were the sorts of steps that had to be taken, and 1 am not arguing with that particular policy of the past. I do not want to continue for any length of time, but I want to make one or two observations about revaluation. Senator O'Byrne made the relevant point. The Australian Country Party did not want revaluation, despite the fact that all the expert knowledge that was available to the previous Government said: You should revalue the Australian dollar'. The Country Party, which was holding a gun at the head of the Liberal Party, said: 'You will not revalue the dollar because this is not in the interests of the country people, and therefore the country at large can be held to ransom'. We inherited the problem in relation to the value of the Australian dollar.

continue.para: I noticed that Senator Rae made the comment: ' I do not challenge the decision of the Government on revaluation'. 1 think he is quite right. This of course indicates the sort of incompatability that existed in the previous coalition Government, and I have no doubt that it still exists today in the opposition parties. I do not wish to pursue this matter any further than to say that I can assure Senator Wright, as the initiator of this debate, that I will do all I can to make the apple and pear industry in Tasmania a viable industry. I can assure him that there is in this Government as much or more concern for the social effects on that industry, should it collapse, than there was in the previous Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
